title: Eclampsia / Seizure in Pregnancy
icd10: G40.909 (Epilepsy in pregnancy — known epilepsy presenting during pregnancy)
scope: ** Neurological evaluation and management of seizures occurring during pregnancy and the postpartum period. Covers eclamptic seizures, PRES overlap with eclampsia, management of known epilepsy during pregnancy, acute seizure treatment including magnesium sulfate protocol, blood pressure management, fetal considerations, and postpartum seizure management. Excludes isolated preeclampsia without seizure (obstetric management), non-pregnant seizure evaluation (see New Onset Seizure), and chronic epilepsy management (see Epilepsy Chronic Management).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: HELLP syndrome screening (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelets); DIC; infection; baseline for delivery planning
Hepatic transaminases (HELLP); renal function (preeclampsia with severe features); electrolytes; glucose; uric acid trend
Essential/Core Labs.target: AST/ALT <70 IU/L; elevated → HELLP/severe preeclampsia; creatinine <0.9 mg/dL; elevated → renal involvement

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Elevated in preeclampsia; correlates with disease severity; useful trending parameter
Essential/Core Labs.target: <5.5 mg/dL in pregnancy; >6.0 → severe preeclampsia; trend upward concerning

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hemolysis marker for HELLP; elevated LDH with low haptoglobin and schistocytes confirms hemolysis
Essential/Core Labs.target: <600 IU/L; elevated → hemolysis component of HELLP

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy screening; DIC in severe preeclampsia/HELLP; baseline before delivery
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; fibrinogen <300 mg/dL concerning (normally elevated in pregnancy >400); DIC if fibrinogen <200 + elevated D-dimer

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hemolysis marker; absent or very low in HELLP
Schistocytes confirm microangiopathic hemolysis (HELLP, TTP, HUS)
Proteinuria confirms preeclampsia diagnosis; quantification needed
Rapid assessment of proteinuria; correlates with 24h collection; >0.3 diagnostic
Hypoglycemia as seizure cause; gestational diabetes assessment
Baseline before MgSO4 therapy; monitor during infusion for toxicity; therapeutic range 4-7 mEq/L for seizure prophylaxis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Baseline 1.5-2.5 mEq/L; therapeutic on MgSO4: 4-7 mEq/L; toxic >7 (loss of reflexes), >10 (respiratory depression), >12 (cardiac arrest)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypocalcemia as seizure cause; MgSO4 can cause hypocalcemia
Preparation for potential emergent delivery; hemorrhage risk in HELLP/DIC

Essential/Core Labs.item: ASM levels (if on ASMs for epilepsy) (CPT 80201-80299)
Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Pregnancy alters ASM pharmacokinetics (increased clearance, volume distribution, decreased protein binding); levels often subtherapeutic
Essential/Core Labs.target: Compare to pre-pregnancy baseline; lamotrigine drops 50-70%; levetiracetam drops ~60%; free levels preferred

Extended Workup.rationale: DIC screening; normally elevated in pregnancy but very high suggests DIC
Extended Workup.target: Mildly elevated (normal in pregnancy); markedly elevated → DIC

Extended Workup.rationale: Elevated in hemolytic anemia (HELLP); marrow response to hemolysis
Extended Workup.target: Elevated → active hemolysis; low → marrow suppression

Extended Workup.rationale: Thyroid storm can cause seizures; postpartum thyroiditis
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) can cause seizures; valproate encephalopathy if on VPA
Extended Workup.target: <35 μmol/L; elevated → AFLP or VPA toxicity

Extended Workup.rationale: Pancreatitis associated with HELLP; severe epigastric pain evaluation
Postictal elevation; persistent elevation → hemodynamic compromise or hepatic dysfunction
Extended Workup.target: Mildly elevated postictal (resolves in 2h); persistent → concerning

Extended Workup.rationale: Adrenal insufficiency (Sheehan syndrome in postpartum); normally elevated in pregnancy

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) can mimic HELLP/eclampsia; low ADAMTS13 (<10%) diagnostic
Antiphospholipid syndrome increases preeclampsia and stroke risk; lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, anti-β2-glycoprotein I
Low in lupus nephritis, atypical HUS, complement-mediated TMA mimicking preeclampsia
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; low → autoimmune or complement-mediated process

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If seizures refractory to MgSO4 and antihypertensives; atypical presentation; postpartum encephalitis
Cocaine, methamphetamine → hypertensive crisis and seizures in pregnancy; occult substance use
If early-onset severe preeclampsia (<34 weeks); recurrent preeclampsia; factor V Leiden, prothrombin mutation, protein C/S, antithrombin III
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; positive → hematology referral for future pregnancy planning

Essential/First-line.timing: First-line acute imaging if eclamptic seizure; rule out hemorrhage, edema, herniation; safe in pregnancy (low dose, shield abdomen)
Essential/First-line.target: No hemorrhage; may show posterior cerebral edema (PRES pattern); mass effect
Essential/First-line.contraindications: None (shield abdomen; benefit outweighs minimal fetal risk)

Essential/First-line.timing: Preferred imaging after initial CT; PRES evaluation (T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in posterior cerebral regions); no gadolinium in pregnancy unless absolutely necessary
Essential/First-line.target: **PRES**: bilateral symmetric T2/FLAIR hyperintensity in parieto-occipital regions; may involve frontal, temporal, brainstem, cerebellum; DWI to differentiate vasogenic (PRES) from cytotoxic edema (stroke)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; avoid gadolinium if possible (crosses placenta)

Essential/First-line.timing: If concern for cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT), arterial dissection, or vasospasm; CVT risk elevated in pregnancy/postpartum
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; CVT (absent flow in sinuses); arterial narrowing → vasospasm (RCVS overlap); dissection

Essential/First-line.timing: Cardiac evaluation; arrhythmia; cardiomyopathy (peripartum); magnesium effects on conduction
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; PR prolongation (Mg effect); arrhythmia → cardiology

Essential/First-line.timing: Fetal heart rate monitoring; assess for fetal distress during/after maternal seizure; placental abruption detection
Essential/First-line.target: Reassuring FHR (reactive NST); non-reassuring → emergent delivery planning

Extended.timing: Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT); pregnancy/postpartum is major risk factor; headache + seizure + focal deficit → must exclude
If seizures recur despite MgSO4; diagnostic uncertainty (eclampsia vs epilepsy vs NCSE); persistent altered mental status
Extended.target: Normal background or diffuse slowing (eclampsia); epileptiform discharges → epilepsy; NCSE patterns

Extended.timing: Persistent altered mental status after eclamptic seizure; concern for NCSE; refractory seizures
Peripartum cardiomyopathy; pulmonary edema in severe preeclampsia; cardiac function assessment
Extended.target: Normal EF (>55%); reduced EF → peripartum cardiomyopathy; pulmonary hypertension

Extended.timing: Pulmonary edema (common in severe preeclampsia); aspiration after seizure; ETT position
Extended.target: Clear lungs; bilateral edema → fluid overload/preeclampsia; infiltrate → aspiration

Extended.timing: Fetal viability and growth; placental abruption evaluation; amniotic fluid assessment
Extended.target: Normal fetal growth; abruption → emergent delivery; oligohydramnios → uteroplacental insufficiency

Rare/Specialized.timing: If concern for vasospasm (RCVS), arterial dissection, or aneurysm; when MRA unavailable or inconclusive
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Contrast risk to fetus (use only if MRA unavailable and diagnosis critical); iodinated contrast crosses placenta

Rare/Specialized.timing: Gold standard for cerebral vasospasm if imaging equivocal and clinical suspicion high
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Invasive; radiation; contrast; reserve for equivocal cases

Acute/Emergent.indication: **FIRST-LINE for eclamptic seizures and seizure prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia**; superior to phenytoin and diazepam for eclampsia

doseOptions.orderSentence: Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) — loading dose 4-6 g IV over 15-20 min IV

dosing.instructions: 4-6 g IV loading dose in 100 mL NS over 15-20 min; Zuspan regimen: 4 g IV load + 1 g/h maintenance; Pritchard regimen: 4 g IV + 10 g IM load (5 g each buttock) + 5 g IM q4h
dosing.orderSentence: Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) — loading dose 4-6 g IV over 15-20 min IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Myasthenia gravis; severe renal failure (adjust dose); heart block
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Magnesium level q4-6h (target 4-7 mEq/L); deep tendon reflexes q1h (FIRST SIGN of toxicity = loss of patellar reflex); respiratory rate q1h (>12/min); urine output q1h (>25 mL/h); have calcium gluconate at bedside

Acute/Emergent.indication: Continued seizure prophylaxis after loading dose; continue for 24-48h postpartum (eclampsia risk persists postpartum)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) — maintenance 1-2 g/h continuous infusion IV

dosing.instructions: 1 g/h standard maintenance; increase to 2 g/h if seizure recurs or in severe preeclampsia; continue 24h postpartum (48h if persistent severe features); reduce to 0.5 g/h if CrCl <30
dosing.orderSentence: Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) — maintenance 1-2 g/h continuous infusion IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Same as loading; monitor for toxicity
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Same as loading; reduce dose if reflexes diminish or urine output drops

Acute/Emergent.indication: **MAGNESIUM TOXICITY RESCUE**: Respiratory depression, loss of reflexes, cardiac arrest from Mg toxicity

doseOptions.orderSentence: Calcium gluconate (MgSO4 antidote) 1 g IV over 3 min IV

dosing.instructions: 1 g (10 mL of 10% solution) IV over 3 min; may repeat; MUST be at bedside whenever MgSO4 infusing
dosing.orderSentence: Calcium gluconate (MgSO4 antidote) 1 g IV over 3 min IV

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Cardiac monitoring; respiratory status; repeat Mg level

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line antihypertensive for acute severe hypertension in pregnancy (SBP ≥160 or DBP ≥110); prevents stroke

dosing.instructions: 20 mg IV push over 2 min; if BP not controlled in 10 min → 40 mg; then 80 mg; max 300 mg total; then start infusion 1-2 mg/min

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Asthma; decompensated heart failure; second/third-degree heart block; heart rate <60
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP q5 min during IV bolus; heart rate; fetal monitoring (labetalol safe in pregnancy)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Second-line antihypertensive for acute severe hypertension in pregnancy; alternative when labetalol contraindicated

dosing.instructions: 5 mg IV over 1-2 min; if BP not controlled in 20 min → repeat 5-10 mg; max 20 mg total; then reassess

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Coronary artery disease; mitral stenosis; tachycardia
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP q5 min; heart rate (reflex tachycardia common); fetal monitoring

Acute/Emergent.indication: Oral antihypertensive for severe hypertension when IV access delayed or as transition from IV therapy

dosing.instructions: 10-20 mg PO; may repeat in 30 min if needed; max 30 mg in acute setting; transition to extended-release 30-60 mg daily

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Concurrent MgSO4 (theoretical concern for potentiated hypotension — monitor closely but combination is used); severe aortic stenosis
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP q15 min after first dose; fetal monitoring; avoid sublingual route (unpredictable absorption)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Second-line for eclamptic seizure not responding to MgSO4; or while MgSO4 loading in progress

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV push over 2 min; may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg; benzodiazepines cross placenta — anticipate neonatal sedation

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Severe respiratory depression; use only if MgSO4 inadequate; short-term use only
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Respiratory rate; SpO2; neonatal assessment at delivery; have airway equipment ready

Acute/Emergent.indication: ASM for recurrent seizures after MgSO4 failure; preferred over phenytoin in pregnancy due to better safety profile; for known epilepsy patients needing IV loading

dosing.instructions: Load 1000-1500 mg IV over 15 min; maintenance 500-1000 mg IV/PO q12h; renal dosing if CrCl <50

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Renal function; psychiatric side effects; safe in pregnancy (low teratogenicity); safe in breastfeeding

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache in eclampsia/preeclampsia; safe in pregnancy; first-line analgesic

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 3000 mg/day in pregnancy; avoid in hepatic impairment (HELLP)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment (HELLP with transaminases >5x ULN); allergy

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea/vomiting in eclampsia/severe preeclampsia; safe in pregnancy

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV/PO q8h PRN; max 16 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: QT prolongation; first trimester concern (some data, generally considered safe)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Transition from IV to oral BP control in preeclampsia; maintenance antihypertensive

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg PO BID; increase by 100 mg q12h as needed; target BP <150/100 antepartum; max 2400 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Oral antihypertensive maintenance for preeclampsia; calcium channel blocker safe in pregnancy

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily; increase by 30 mg q3-7d; max 120 mg/day; swallow whole, do not crush

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: BP; heart rate; peripheral edema; fetal monitoring

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Third-line for eclamptic seizures refractory to MgSO4 + lorazepam; historically used but INFERIOR to MgSO4 for eclampsia

dosing.instructions: 20 mg phenytoin equivalents (PE)/kg IV at ≤150 mg PE/min; maintenance 5 mg PE/kg/day; check free phenytoin level (protein binding altered in pregnancy)

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Sinus bradycardia; second/third-degree AV block; Stokes-Adams syndrome; **TERATOGENIC** (fetal hydantoin syndrome) — use only if no alternative
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Cardiac monitoring during infusion; free phenytoin level (not total); BP; fetal monitoring

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Refractory severe hypertension not controlled by labetalol + hydralazine; ICU setting

doseOptions.orderSentence: Nicardipine infusion 5 mg/h titrated to 15 mg/h IV

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg/h IV; increase by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; max 15 mg/h; target SBP 140-155; reduce BP no more than 25% in first hour
dosing.orderSentence: Nicardipine infusion 5 mg/h titrated to 15 mg/h IV

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Arterial line; continuous BP; fetal monitoring

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Life-threatening hypertensive emergency refractory to all other agents; LAST RESORT in pregnancy due to cyanide risk to fetus

dosing.instructions: Start 0.25 mcg/kg/min; titrate by 0.5 mcg/kg/min q5min; max 2 mcg/kg/min; use for shortest duration possible; **CYANIDE TOXICITY risk to fetus — LAST RESORT**

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Compensatory hypertension; hepatic insufficiency; coarctation of aorta
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Arterial line mandatory; thiocyanate levels if >24h; **FETAL MONITORING — cyanide crosses placenta**

Second-line/Refractory.indication: **DEFINITIVE TREATMENT for eclampsia**: Delivery of fetus and placenta cures eclampsia in most cases

dosing.instructions: Plan delivery after maternal stabilization (seizure control + BP control); ≥34 weeks: delivery recommended; <34 weeks: consider steroids for fetal lung maturity if maternal condition allows 24-48h delay; emergent C-section if fetal distress

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Continuous fetal monitoring; maternal hemodynamics; postpartum MgSO4 continuation 24-48h

ASM Safety in Pregnancy / Postpartum.indication: Preferred ASM in pregnancy for known epilepsy; lowest teratogenicity risk among effective broad-spectrum ASMs; requires dose monitoring

dosing.instructions: Monitor levels monthly during pregnancy (drops 50-70%); increase dose to maintain pre-pregnancy level; reduce dose by 25% within first 2 weeks postpartum then rapidly taper to pre-pregnancy dose over next 2 weeks

ASM Safety in Pregnancy / Postpartum.contraindications: SJS/TEN with rapid dose changes; do not increase faster than 50 mg q2wk
ASM Safety in Pregnancy / Postpartum.monitoring: Monthly lamotrigine levels; postpartum level within 1 week of delivery; toxicity symptoms (diplopia, ataxia) as levels rebound postpartum

ASM Safety in Pregnancy / Postpartum.indication: Preferred ASM in pregnancy; low teratogenicity; safe in breastfeeding; renal elimination (no hepatic interactions)

dosing.instructions: Monitor levels each trimester (decreases ~60%); increase dose to maintain seizure control; renal clearance increases in pregnancy; postpartum dose reduction needed

ASM Safety in Pregnancy / Postpartum.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; dose adjust for renal function
ASM Safety in Pregnancy / Postpartum.monitoring: Levels each trimester; psychiatric symptoms; renal function; postpartum reduction

ASM Safety in Pregnancy / Postpartum.indication: Neural tube defect prevention in women with epilepsy; ALL women on ASMs planning pregnancy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Folic acid (high-dose preconception) 4 mg daily PO

dosing.instructions: 4 mg daily starting ≥3 months before conception; continue through first trimester; 1 mg daily maintenance after
dosing.orderSentence: Folic acid (high-dose preconception) 4 mg daily PO

ASM Safety in Pregnancy / Postpartum.indication: All neonates born to mothers on enzyme-inducing ASMs; hemorrhagic disease of newborn prevention

doseOptions.orderSentence: Vitamin K (neonatal) 1 mg IM at birth IM

dosing.instructions: 1 mg vitamin K IM to neonate at delivery; standard of care but especially critical with enzyme-inducing maternal ASMs
dosing.orderSentence: Vitamin K (neonatal) 1 mg IM at birth IM

ASM Safety in Pregnancy / Postpartum.monitoring: Neonatal coagulation studies if clinically indicated

Referrals & Consults.item: OB/GYN or Maternal-Fetal Medicine (MFM) STAT consultation for all eclamptic seizures for delivery planning and fetal assessment
Neurology consultation for eclamptic seizure evaluation; PRES vs CVT vs other neurological cause; ASM management in known epilepsy
Anesthesiology consultation for delivery planning; epidural/spinal safety; airway assessment if intubated; magnesium-neuromuscular blocker interactions
Neonatology or pediatrics notification for delivery; assess neonatal effects of maternal seizure, magnesium, and ASMs
Hematology consultation if HELLP with severe thrombocytopenia (<50K), suspected TTP (ADAMTS13 pending), or DIC
Nephrology consultation if acute kidney injury (creatinine >1.1 mg/dL in pregnancy) or persistent proteinuria postpartum
Postpartum neurology follow-up in 2-4 weeks for MRI review, ASM management, and recurrence risk counseling
Postpartum OB follow-up in 1-2 weeks for BP monitoring, proteinuria resolution, and future pregnancy counseling

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if new seizure, severe headache not responsive to acetaminophen, visual changes (blurring, scotomata, blindness), right upper quadrant pain, or sudden swelling of face/hands (preeclampsia warning signs)
Continue magnesium sulfate monitoring in hospital for 24-48 hours after delivery; do not leave against medical advice during this critical window
Postpartum eclampsia can occur up to 6 weeks after delivery; any new seizure, severe headache, or visual changes in the postpartum period requires emergency evaluation
If on ASMs for epilepsy: do NOT stop medications during pregnancy; benefits of seizure prevention outweigh teratogenicity risk of most ASMs; discuss any changes with neurologist
Breastfeeding is generally safe with most ASMs (lamotrigine, levetiracetam, valproate, carbamazepine); monitor infant for sedation; discuss with neurologist and pediatrician
Monitor blood pressure at home daily for 6 weeks postpartum using validated automated cuff; record and bring to follow-up; seek care if SBP ≥150 or DBP ≥100
Future pregnancies: preeclampsia recurrence risk is 15-25%; eclampsia recurrence ~2%; discuss timing and planning with MFM

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Low-dose aspirin 81 mg daily starting at 12-16 weeks in future pregnancies for preeclampsia prevention (recommended for women with prior preeclampsia/eclampsia)
Blood pressure optimization before future pregnancies; target <130/80; weight management and regular exercise reduce preeclampsia risk
Calcium supplementation 1000-2000 mg daily in future pregnancies may reduce preeclampsia risk (especially if baseline dietary calcium is low)
Adequate sleep and stress management during pregnancy and postpartum to reduce seizure threshold and support recovery
Smoking cessation and alcohol avoidance throughout pregnancy and postpartum

differential.features: New-onset seizure in pregnancy/postpartum with hypertension (≥140/90) and proteinuria; >20 weeks gestation; may occur without preceding preeclampsia diagnosis
differential.tests: BP, urinalysis, preeclampsia labs; clinical diagnosis

differential.features: Overlaps heavily with eclampsia; posterior cerebral edema on MRI; may occur with or without eclampsia
differential.tests: MRI (T2/FLAIR posterior predominant edema); DWI (vasogenic not cytotoxic edema); clinical overlap — treat both

differential.features: Headache, seizures, focal deficits; pregnancy/postpartum is major risk factor; may have hemorrhagic infarct
differential.tests: MRV (absent venous flow); D-dimer (very elevated); CT venogram

differential.features: Pre-existing seizure disorder; may have breakthrough due to decreased ASM levels; no hypertension/proteinuria
differential.tests: ASM levels (subtherapeutic); normal BP; no proteinuria; prior epilepsy history

differential.features: Sudden focal deficit; may have seizure at onset; pregnancy increases ischemic stroke risk 3-13x
differential.tests: MRI/DWI (restricted diffusion); CTA/MRA (occlusion); onset with focal deficit

differential.features: Severe headache; focal deficit; may have seizure; hypertension; coagulopathy (HELLP/DIC)
differential.tests: CT head (hyperdense lesion); coagulation studies; platelet count

differential.features: Thunderclap headache; seizures; focal deficits; angiography shows segmental vasoconstriction; overlaps with eclampsia/PRES
differential.tests: CTA/MRA (multifocal narrowing); serial imaging (resolves over weeks)

differential.features: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia + thrombocytopenia; may mimic HELLP; seizures from TMA
Fever, headache, altered mental status, seizures; may be viral (HSV) or bacterial
differential.tests: CSF analysis; MRI (temporal lobe enhancement in HSV); cultures

differential.features: Third trimester; nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, coagulopathy, hypoglycemia, hyperammonemia
differential.tests: Ammonia (elevated); glucose (low); fibrinogen (low); LFTs (elevated); imaging (fatty liver)

evidence.recommendation: Magnesium sulfate superior to phenytoin and diazepam for eclampsia prevention and treatment
MgSO4 reduces eclampsia risk by 58% compared to placebo in severe preeclampsia
Labetalol and nifedipine equally effective for acute severe hypertension in pregnancy
PRES is the neuroimaging correlate of eclampsia in majority of cases
Low-dose aspirin 81 mg from 12-16 weeks reduces preeclampsia risk in high-risk women
Lamotrigine and levetiracetam preferred ASMs in pregnancy (lowest teratogenicity)
Lamotrigine levels decrease 50-70% during pregnancy; monthly monitoring needed
Delivery is definitive treatment for eclampsia; timing depends on gestational age and maternal/fetal status
evidence.source: [ACOG Practice Bulletin 222: Gestational Hypertension and Preeclampsia 2020](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32443079/)

evidence.recommendation: Postpartum eclampsia occurs in up to 26% of eclampsia cases; monitoring continues 48h post-delivery
evidence.source: [Al-Safi et al. Am J Obstet Gynecol 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21282835/)

evidence.recommendation: CVT risk is 12x higher in pregnancy/postpartum; must be excluded in seizures with headache

monitoring.frequency: q5 min during acute treatment; q15 min x 2h; then q1h; q4h once stable
q4-6h during infusion; q6h maintenance; PRN if toxicity signs
monitoring.action: <4 → increase rate; >7 → decrease rate/hold; >10 → stop + calcium gluconate
Absent/diminished → check Mg level; hold MgSO4 if areflexic; have calcium gluconate ready
<12 → hold MgSO4; administer calcium gluconate; prepare for intubation
<25 mL/h → reduce MgSO4 (renal excretion); assess volume status; oliguria → fluid bolus vs renal failure
Non-reassuring → OB assessment; emergent delivery if persistent fetal distress

monitoring.frequency: q6-12h if HELLP; daily if preeclampsia
monitoring.action: Falling platelets → worsening HELLP; Hgb drop → hemorrhage or hemolysis

monitoring.frequency: q6-12h if HELLP; daily if preeclampsia
monitoring.action: Rising → worsening HELLP; peak usually 24-48h after delivery then improve
Worsening → ongoing hemolysis; not improving 48-72h → consider TTP/aHUS

monitoring.frequency: At admission; monthly during pregnancy; 1 week postpartum
monitoring.action: Subtherapeutic → increase dose; postpartum → reduce dose (levels rebound)

monitoring.frequency: Daily x 72h inpatient; home monitoring daily x 6 weeks
monitoring.action: Persistent hypertension → continue/escalate antihypertensives; new onset >48h → evaluate late postpartum preeclampsia

disposition.criteria: Eclamptic seizure; refractory hypertension (≥160/110 despite 2 IV agents); HELLP with platelets <50K or DIC; pulmonary edema; renal failure; persistent altered mental status; intubation
Severe preeclampsia with controlled BP; stable HELLP (platelets >50K); post-eclamptic seizure now stable; pending delivery planning
Seizure-free ≥24h after MgSO4 completion; BP consistently <150/100 on oral agents; normalizing labs; oral medications tolerated; reliable follow-up arranged; home BP cuff provided
Neurology 2-4 weeks (MRI review, recurrence risk); OB 1-2 weeks (BP, proteinuria); MFM before future pregnancy for risk counseling
If facility lacks MFM, NICU, or neurocritical care capabilities; HELLP with DIC; refractory status epilepticus in pregnancy
